alternateName: 4‑class (Suicidal, Depression, Anxiety, Normal) mental health text dataset

distribution.name: archive.zip
distribution.description: Archive containing all the contents of the Mental Health Text Classification Dataset dataset

distribution.name: mental_health_combined_test.csv
distribution.description: `mental_health_combined_test.csv` is the **balanced test split** with **992 samples** (248 per class: Suicidal, Depression, Anxiety, Normal). It contains two columns—`text` (cleaned post) and `status` (final label)—and is created by combining held‑out data from the source datasets, cleaning, mapping labels, removing duplicates, and downsampling each class to equal size for fair evaluation.

distribution.name: mental_heath_feature_engineered.csv
distribution.description: `mental_health_feature_engineered.csv` is a **cleaned and feature‑engineered** subset of mental‑health texts, with each row containing the original `text`, its `status` label (Suicidal, Depression, Anxiety, Normal), and several handcrafted features. These include `Unique_ID`, `text_length`, `word_count`, `num_urls`, `num_emojis`, `num_special_chars`, `num_excess_punct`, and `avg_word_length`, enabling quick classical baselines and feature analysis in addition to deep NLP models.

distribution.name: mental_heath_unbanlanced.csv
distribution.description: `mental_heath_unbanlanced.csv` is the **main training corpus** with **48,945 samples** and a realistic, unbalanced class distribution (Normal, Depression, Suicidal, Anxiety). Each row contains `text` (cleaned post) and `status` (final label), created by merging the cleaned source datasets, mapping labels to four classes, and removing duplicates **without** any class balancing.

These include `Unique_ID`, `text_length`, `word_count`, `num_urls`, `num_emojis`, `num_special_chars`, `num_excess_punct`, and `avg_word_length`, enabling quick classical baselines and feature analysis in addition to deep NLP models.

keywords: subject > health and fitness > health > health conditions > mental health
name: Mental Health Text Classification Dataset
description:
This dataset contains labeled mental‑health–related text posts for **4‑class classification**: **Suicidal**, **Depression**, **Anxiety**, and **Normal**. It is built by combining and preprocessing samples from three public datasets, then creating an **unbalanced main training corpus**, a **strictly balanced test set**, and an additional **feature‑engineered sentiment dataset** for analysis and modeling.

***

## Source Datasets

This dataset is a **derived work** based on the following sources (raw data from these sources is *not* redistributed; only processed, combined samples are included).

### Suicide and Depression Detection (Kaggle)

- **Name:** Suicide and Depression Detection
- **Author:** Nikhileswar Komati
- **Link:** https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/nikhileswarkomati/suicide-watch
- **Content:** 232,074 Reddit posts from suicide‑related communities, labeled as suicidal vs non‑suicidal / depression vs control.


### Sentiment Analysis for Mental Health (Kaggle)

- **Name:** Sentiment Analysis for Mental Health
- **Author:** Suchintika Sarkar
- **Link:** https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/suchintikasarkar/sentiment-analysis-for-mental-health
- **Content:** Over 44,000 text statements labeled into multiple mental‑health categories such as normal, depression, suicide, anxiety, stress, bipolarity, and personality disorder.


### Reddit Mental Health Classification (Murarka et al.)

- **Name:** Reddit Mental Health Classification Dataset
- **Paper:** Murarka, A., Radhakrishnan, B., \& Ravichandran, S. (2021). *Detection and Classification of Mental Illnesses on Social Media using RoBERTa.*
- **Link:** https://github.com/amurark/mental-health-detection (mirror: https://github.com/amurark/mental-health-classification)
- **Content:** Reddit posts from mental‑health subreddits labeled into ADHD, Anxiety, Bipolar, Depression, PTSD, and None.

> **Important:** The raw data from these sources is **not redistributed** here. All provided files are cleaned, transformed, and re‑split into derivatives.

***

## Files and Features

### 1. Unbalanced Main Training Set

The primary training data preserves **real‑world class imbalance** after cleaning, label mapping, and deduplication.

- **Total samples:** 49,612
- **Class distribution:**
    - Normal: 18,391
    - Depression: 14,506
    - Suicidal: 11,212
    - Anxiety: 5,503

Typical columns:

- `text` – Raw or lightly cleaned text.
- `status` – Final label in {Suicidal, Depression, Anxiety, Normal}.

This is the **recommended split for training**, especially if you want to study models under realistic class skew.

### 2. Balanced Test Set

- **File:** `mental_health_combined_test.csv`
- **Samples:** 992 (strictly balanced)
    - 248 samples per class (Suicidal, Depression, Anxiety, Normal).

Columns:

- `text`
- `status` (four‑class label)

This file is intended as the **final evaluation set** and should remain unseen during training.

### 3. Feature‑Engineered Sentiment Dataset

Derived from the *Sentiment Analysis for Mental Health* source, cleaned and enriched with basic handcrafted features.

Core columns:

- `Unique_ID` – Row identifier.
- `text` – Cleaned statement/post text.
- `status` – Normalized label (e.g., Suicidal, Depression, Anxiety, Normal after mapping).

Engineered feature columns:

- `text_length` – Total number of characters in the text.
- `word_count` – Number of whitespace‑separated tokens.
- `num_urls` – Count of URL patterns (e.g., `http`, `https`, `www`).
- `num_emojis` – Count of emoji characters (basic Unicode emoji detection).
- `num_special_chars` – Count of non‑alphanumeric characters (e.g., `@`, `#`, `$`, `%`, `&`).
- `num_excess_punct` – Count of repeated punctuation sequences (e.g., `!!!`, `???`, `...`).
- `avg_word_length` – Average number of characters per word.

These features support quick classical baselines, feature‑importance analysis, and hybrid models that combine deep embeddings with simple text statistics.

If you also include `mental_health_balanced_train.csv` (~9,599 rows), describe it as a **downsampled, approximately balanced training subset** created by capping the number of samples per class for convenience experiments, not as the main training distribution.

***

## Preprocessing and Labeling

A unified pipeline was used across sources:

- **Text cleaning:**
    - Removed rows with missing text or labels.
    - Dropped duplicate posts based on `text`.
    - Normalized whitespace and basic formatting via regex.
    - Filtered out extremely short and extremely long texts to remove non‑informative samples.[^1]
- **Label standardization (4 classes):**
    - Suicide / suicidal ideation → `Suicidal`
    - Depression / depressed → `Depression`
    - Anxiety‑related labels → `Anxiety`
    - Control / non‑suicidal / normal → `Normal`
    - Other labels (e.g., stress, bipolar, personality disorder, PTSD, unclear) were excluded to maintain a clean four‑class space.

***

## Split Strategy

Final splits are **new** and do not match any original Kaggle or GitHub splits.

- **Training (main):**
    - 49,612 unbalanced samples with the class counts listed above.
- **Validation:**
    - Users should create their own **stratified validation split** from the training file (for example, 10–20% hold‑out) while keeping the official test set unseen.
- **Test:**
    - 992 samples in `mental_health_combined_test.csv`, with 248 examples per class (fully balanced).

***

## Intended Use and Limitations

The dataset is designed for:

- Mental‑health **text classification**, including suicide‑risk, depression, and anxiety detection.
- Studying **class imbalance**, feature engineering, and robustness of NLP models on social‑media text.
- Educational and research use in mental‑health NLP; **not** for clinical or crisis decision‑making.[^5][^6]

Key limitations:

- **Domain bias:** Mostly Reddit and similar platforms; may not generalize to clinical notes or other apps.
- **Label noise:** Labels are not clinical diagnoses and may be noisy, sarcastic, or ambiguous.
- **Limited diagnostic coverage:** Only four final labels (Suicidal, Depression, Anxiety, Normal); other conditions are discarded.
- **Demographic unknowns:** No reliable demographic metadata, so potential demographic and cultural biases cannot be quantified.
- **Safety:** Research and educational use only; real‑world deployment requires clinicians, extra validation, and safety mechanisms.

***

## Recommended Citation

Please cite the original sources and this derived dataset, for example:

- Komati, N. *Suicide and Depression Detection* $$

- Sarkar, S. *Sentiment Analysis for Mental Health* $$

- Murarka, A., Radhakrishnan, B., \& Ravichandran, S. (2021). *Detection and Classification of Mental Illnesses on Social Media using RoBERTa* $$
Dataset and code

And for your Kaggle release:
